engineeringPark.name: 3D-Printed Puzzles
engineeringPark.description: Various interactive puzzles that were designed in AutoCAD and printed using 3D Printers.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Scott Williamson, Liam Callahan, Mia Sitzler, Hannah Van Fleet, Daniel Yochim, David Wilson, Michael Smith, Alexa Kline, Kaleigh Marcotte.

engineeringPark.name: A Navy Frigate: Heat Exchanger Demo
engineeringPark.description: This interactive exhibit explores the functioning of a heat exchanger from a Navy frigate! This hands-on demonstration allows visitors to learn about the principles of heat exchange both in theory and through their senses. Color-coded hoses and color changing film makes the experience fun for all ages!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Sarah Kirk

engineeringPark.name: ABVI Upcycling: Cotton Insulation
engineeringPark.description: Our goal for this project is to produce a prototype of a insulation made from recycled cotton, such that the customer (Goodwill) will be able to manufacture this product and then make a profit from selling the recycled textiles. The benefit of this product is that it is environmentally friendly, the product can be touched with bare hands and performs equally to that as standard fiberglass insulation.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Mitchell Goepel, Samantha Kon

engineeringPark.name: Active Noise Cancellation
engineeringPark.description: Our group has designed an active noise cancellation system consisting of microphone/speaker pairs and processing software powered by the Strength Pareto Evolutionary Algorithm (SPEA2). The goals of this project are to reduce the overall noise of the work environment within the bandwidth of the average human hearing capabilities in real time with minimal adjustments from the user. Ultimately, this software will be expanded to network with other machines to cancel noise in an entire office.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Matthew Gibson, Vincent Coffey, Nick Venditti

engineeringPark.name: Advanced Gear Manufacturing with Gleason Works
engineeringPark.description: This exhibit is presenting the advanced gear manufacturing processes with a demonstration about how to use the gear hobbing machine to operate gear cutting. Besides that, a presentation about how to operate the gear hobbing analysis to improve the efficiency and the product quality also will be provided to the viewers
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Rui Liu, Eloy Yague-Martinez

engineeringPark.name: Aero Design
engineeringPark.description: The RIT Aero-Design team will have a wind-tunnel demonstration on display. The team will also have their competition aircraft from the 2016-17 AIAA Design Build Fly competition on display as well as other aircraft that were constructed in previous years.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Ian Lengel, Brady Hrabovsky, Robert Morandini, Max Messie, Kyle Prosser, Drew Flickinger

engineeringPark.name: American Institute of Chemical Engineers
engineeringPark.description: Learn about surface tension and check out RC size cars that start and stop on a chemical reaction.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Ashley Bloomfield, Eric Kolb, Dennis Bogdan, Josh Clark, Orianna Henry, Ryan Mazur, Heather Ursino, Ioan Gitsov, Valerie Burger, Maura Sepesy, William Mohr, Matt Bauer, Andrew Fleischer, Quintina Frink, Patricia Valenzuela, Taylor Smith, Melissa Rockhill, Donald Lord

engineeringPark.name: AMPrint Center - Multifunctional 3D Printing
engineeringPark.description: The AMPrint Center is NY State's newest Center for Advanced Technology, and is devoted to Additive Manufacturing and Multifunctional Printing. The Center has 20 different printers, and a variety of associated equipment. Many different kinds of materials can be printed here, including polymers, metals, ceramics, and composites. See demonstrations of many different types of printing processes in action, and take home a souvenir!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Bruce Kahn, Robert Ichiyama, Mark Irving, Susan Rausch, Bill Murray, Khushbu Zope, Denis Cormier, Jessica Jaroszewski, Amy Kahn, Max Kahn, Sally Kahn, Casey Cephas

engineeringPark.name: Automated Player Piano for Handicap Accessibility
engineeringPark.description: A piano designed around the needs for handicapped individuals will be playing music autonomously with and without human musicians playing along with it.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Scott Porter, Matthew Mack , Ben Parnas

engineeringPark.name: Biochar Concrete Roofing Sheets for Nicaragua
engineeringPark.description: Light weight concrete roofing tiles were made for a local non-profit organization called 4 Walls. 4 Walls provides homes to the people of El Sauce Nicaragua. The goal of the project was to replace the current metal roof that could be manufactured locally, at low cost, and prevent rain water from entering the house, as well as animals from nesting in the roof. The group worked to achieve this goal by using concrete and the light weight aggregate of biochar.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Mary Korycansky, Jenn Kane, Luqman Zainalabidin, Rory Little, Carmen Azzaretti

engineeringPark.name: Biomechanical Elbow Model
engineeringPark.description: The objective of this project is to create a physical model that can demonstrate the proper relationship between the position of the hand/wrist and the different muscles.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Amanda Cook, Maria Romero-Creel, Shannon Keenan, Chris Harley

engineeringPark.name: Cat Cart: A Feline Mobility Assistive
engineeringPark.description: Some of our furry friends need a bit more help than others. This was the case for two local cats born with some degree of paralysis in their rear legs. Our senior design project was granted the task of creating a cart for each cat to improve their mobility and quality of life. The carts are a low cost and do-it-yourself initiative whose designs may be freely distributed to help disabled cats everywhere. Stop by our exhibit to see our clients, Trey and Delilah, in action using their carts!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Sarah Stoltzfus, Jeff Wayman, Matthieu Dora, Colin Lemen, Ed Hanzlik, Karla Weller-Barkley

engineeringPark.name: Compression Cycle Simulation Test Rig
engineeringPark.description: Our custom test rig simulates the compression cycle created by a large piston compressor. The air pressure cycle is created through the use of compressed air, computer-controlled valves, and a custom built pressure tank. Inside the pressure vessel is a section of poppet valves that open and close allowing the pressure cycle to occur. The objective of this test rig is to measure the vibrations of these poppet valves in order to detect different types of failures associated with the poppet valves.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Brandon Chrysler, Alex Grassl, Ryan Muchard, Carvey Yung

engineeringPark.name: Continuous Classroom Vermicomposter
engineeringPark.description: The continuous classroom vermicomposter is a system for the treatment of food wastes using rapid composting. A colony of earthworms are used to assist in breaking down compost into rich condensed soil that can be used in farming and producing organic plant fertilizer.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Erik Freeman, Niall O'Dowd, Jay Patel

engineeringPark.name: Continuous System for Fly Larvae Composting
engineeringPark.description: This system enables facilities to efficiently compost more waste with a smaller footprint, eliminating the environmental effects of hauling waste to landfills and bio-digester facilities. It is easy to clean, allowing larvae to migrate for harvesting, and allows flies to lay eggs. This is suitable in climates that are not naturally suited for BSFL.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Erinne Munie, Ryan Hochreiter, Taylor Hogan

engineeringPark.name: ElectroPhotographic Test Bed
engineeringPark.description: 2017 Senior Design Team has upgraded an existing Electrophotographic Test Bed with a new structure to be used for experimental and research purposes.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Ankit Prasad, Brandon Miller, Stephanie Boula, Dr. Marcos Esterman, Bill Novak

engineeringPark.name: Fluids are Fun - Air Cannon
engineeringPark.description: A flow of fluid can produce a great amount of force on objects. By sealing the barrel of an Air Cannon with nerf balls and compressed air, we can generate enough force to launch the nerf balls a great distance into the air.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Tzu-Ting Hsu, Eric Pareis, Graham Ardner, Tim Landschoot

engineeringPark.name: Fluids are Fun - Bernoulli Blower
engineeringPark.description: This exhibit is an interactive demonstration of the Bernoulli principle and by relation the Bernoulli Blower. Several small scale Bernoulli Blowers are available to pick up and use. Additionally, there is a large, table mounted Bernoulli Blower that can be used to levitate beach-balls. Both types have various fittings to interact with, such as nozzles, tubes, and angled elbows.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Tzu-Ting Hsu, Jesse Fronckowiak, Devin Cooley, Adam Stock, Sushmita Shetti

engineeringPark.name: Fluids are Fun - Laminar Flow Table
engineeringPark.description: Participants place objects on a table in flowing water to see waves like the ones that cars, planes, boats, and other vehicles make as they move through the air or water.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Tzu-Ting Hsu, Patrick McGaw, Corry Straathof, Jason Liu

engineeringPark.name: Fluids are Fun - MR Fluids
engineeringPark.description: This exhibit is a demonstration of the ability of magnetorheological (MR) fluids to change viscosity by exposing the fluids to a magnetic field.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Tzu-Ting Hsu, Ignazio Scollo, Wylie McDonald, Matt Santullo

engineeringPark.name: Fluids are Fun - Oobleck
engineeringPark.description: A non-Newtonian fluid is one in which the rate of strain is not linearly proportional to the rate of shear stress. A shear thickening, or dilatant, fluid becomes more viscous, or resistant to flow, as more shear stress is applied. This happens when long, branchy molecules, like starch, get tangled as they move quickly past each other and act like a solid. However, when moving slow, the molecules are able to pass by each other, and act like a liquid.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Tzu-Ting Hsu, Kenny Hass, Hyungsuk Kang

engineeringPark.name: Fluids are Fun - Slow Motion Water Balloons
engineeringPark.description: This exhibit requires two participants: one to get soaked and one to do the soaking! The first person sits below a bucket holding a water balloon. The second person presses a button, which releases the water balloon and records the action in super slow motion! You can view your movie immediately on the monitor and later on YouTube!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Tzu-Ting Hsu, Mary Young, Kayle Pitts

engineeringPark.name: FSAE Composite Tube Winder
engineeringPark.description: Over the past year, our team has designed, manufactured and tested a filament winding machine capable of producing carbon fiber drive shafts and other cylindrical composite parts for the Formula SAE team. The machine is programmable using an easy to use graphical interface that allows for rapid changes to part geometry on the fly. This project highlights the growing trend that automated manufacturing can now be implemented on a very low budget yet still produce high quality components.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Andrew Derhammer, Daniel Wu, Matt Hendler, Jon Washington

engineeringPark.name: Global Coordinated Vaccine Pricing Evaluation
engineeringPark.description: This exhibit will present the experimental results of running a mathematical model that determines the prices of bundles of vaccines for different markets. This exhibit will present the experimental results of running a mathematical model that determines the prices of bundles of vaccines for different markets and what happens when markets decrease their vaccine budget.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Jose Batista Abikarram

engineeringPark.name: Heart Pump and Circulatory System Model
engineeringPark.description: The Heart Pump and Circulatory System Model is designed to assist Biomedical Engineering students here at RIT with understanding how small changes can affect the entire circulatory system. The model shows physiological conditions such as resting, exercising, obesity, and high blood pressure. The students can change parameters then observe how the heart pressure, capillary pressure, and flow rate adapt in the system.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Susan Rhodes, Kevan Bjornson

engineeringPark.name: Heat Transfer and Magnetism
engineeringPark.description: A demonstration using color-changing film and magnets to display the material properties of common metals that cannot be seen with the eye alone. Visitors will be encouraged to explore this hands-on exhibit and "see" for themselves the connection between thermal (heat) and electrical conductivity.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Heather Cottone, Sarah Kirk, Rachael Stroebel, Breanna Jewell

engineeringPark.name: High Altitude Balloon Instrumentation Platform
engineeringPark.description: The goal of this project is to combine communication and image/data collection technologies into a unified platform that can observe near-space environments. The system will acquire telemetry information and sensor data. Data and a live analog video stream will be transmitted to Earth. Captured sensor data and HD video will also be stored to on-board SD cards. A reaction wheel assembly was designed and implemented to stabilize the instrumentation platform about one axis.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Adam Steenkamer, Steven Giewont, Connor Goldberg, Ian Prechtl, Lincoln Glauser, Matthew Zachary, Christopher Schwab, Sydney Kaminski, Dorin Patru

engineeringPark.name: Interactive Thermal Management
engineeringPark.description: Fundamental research of boiling heat transfer will be the focus of the exhibit. Visitors will be able to understand the different ways we use liquids to cool electronics. Visitors will also discover how research in TAMFL is being conducted to overcome many different thermal management issues. Specifically, visitors will be able to see live demonstrations of the in-house developed experimental setups and understand how boiling liquid is used for cooling applications.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Alyssa Recinella, Aranya Chauhan, Arvind Jaikumar, Austin Hayes, Indranil Joshi, Isaac Perez Raya, Jose Luis Gonzalez Hernandez, Pruthvik Raghupathi, Travis Emery, Satish Kandlikar

engineeringPark.name: International House VR
engineeringPark.description: Experience VR! Learn about International Culture through the lens of student life at International House! Fun AND games!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Leo Holman, Ian Effendi

engineeringPark.name: Kon-Tiki Kiln Heat Recovery System
engineeringPark.description: The goal of this project is to heat water to a safe bathing temperature, and, if the temperatures can be held consistently, to pasteurize the water. Because the kiln is used in countries where education can be minimal, operator ease and simple setup are key requirements for the recovery system. Biochar kilns also come in various sizes, so the heat reclamation system should be adaptable to those existing kilns.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Abby Higgins, Kelsey Thompsom, Leah Matczak, Thane Vollbrecht, Eta Santoro

engineeringPark.name: LORD Downhole Test Simulator Feasibility Study
engineeringPark.description: LORD Corporation designs and manufactures multiple vibration isolators for use in downhole drilling. Currently, LORD is sending their product offsite to undergo necessary testing. LORD has tasked our team to determine if an onsite testing facility that will simulate the environment that the vibration isolators would experience downhole could be feasible. Our team has been tasked with creating a feasibility study to ensure that a testing facility for LORD's vibration isolators could be feasible.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Abby Tremont, Daniel Bowers, Hyungsuk Kang, Jason Whyte, Nicholas Fewell, Samuel Zimmerman, Matthew Biron , Gary Werth

engineeringPark.name: Making Microchips and MEMS Sensors
engineeringPark.description: In this exhibit the tiny chips and sensors have dimensions of just a few hundreds of micrometers (the diameter of a human hair) but can sense many physical properties such as pressure, acceleration, humidity, temperature and light. Such sensors are used in automobiles, cell phones, rockets and people. Explore these tiny devices and see how they are made and integrated into microsystems.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Lynn Fuller, Rob Pearson, Thierno Diallo, Jackson Anderson, Adam Wardas, Patsy Cadareanu, Jenna Doran, Kelly Weiskittel, Matt Hartensveld, Jack Kong, Casey Gonta

engineeringPark.name: MAME 3.0: Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator
engineeringPark.description: Arcade Machine emulator that has been designed as a miniature arcade cabinet.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Scott Williamson, Jason Blocklove, Joseph Panaro, Christian Kobb, Luke Murphy, Kaleigh Marcotte

engineeringPark.name: Meet Your Brain
engineeringPark.description: "Meet Your Brain" Workshop presents a new model to help kids develop systems thinking skills.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Mehrafza Mirzazad Barijugh, Leah Fiorucci Combo

engineeringPark.name: MIDIV2
engineeringPark.description: People will be able to walk up to the device, which will be connected to a PC/laptop and speakers, and they'll be able to play the device to produce music, similar to a classic keyboard
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Khaled Albaddah, Matthew Wong, Graham Boylan

engineeringPark.name: MotorMouth Assistive Tablet Case
engineeringPark.description: MotorMouth is a device that helps children with non-verbal Autism do just that! Our wearable tablet case can assist children with this disorder, as well as its coupled conditions, communicate. There are even some fun textures integrated for favorable sensory stimulus. Be sure to visit MotorMouth to learn about Augmentative and Alternative Communication
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Christina Maragioglio, Elizabeth Jackson

engineeringPark.name: Ortho Clinical Blood Sample Suspension Tray
engineeringPark.description: With the help of Ortho Clinical Diagnostics, we have created a sample tray to interface with blood analyzers that keeps red blood cells in suspension. During the HbA1C blood test, lab technicians must manually shake blood samples to redistribute the red blood cells needed for the test. Our tray uses a battery powered vibration motor to keep the red blood cells suspended for the duration of the test for accurate results.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Randi del Rosario, Patrick Bayly, Lezeh Foy, Christopher Kirby, Ana Peredo

engineeringPark.name: Plastic Bottle to Rope Upcycling Machine
engineeringPark.description: Come and recycle your plastic bottles with our bottle to rope machine that cuts and weaves bottles into a very strong rope product. The weaving machine is to be deployed to developing countries, such as Haiti, where it will empower recycling efforts and generate income for local communities.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: William Hollomon , Koby Kubrin , Jordan Reynolds, Albert Lin

engineeringPark.name: Playing Hand - Cricket using Myo Arm-Band
engineeringPark.description: Hand Cricket is a game that can be played by 2 people of all age group.We decide to use the Myo-ArmBand to detect the movement of the arm and further use supervised learning to classify the movement of the arm and calculate the score and other characteristics of the game of cricket, we would make the computer do the same and then in the end announce the winner.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: KARTHIK SIVARAMA KRISHNAN, Srinath Ramachandran, Akash Saha

engineeringPark.name: RIT InMoov: 3D Printed Humanoid Robot
engineeringPark.description: We will exhibit an Inmoov robot, an open-sourced life-sized humanoid 3D-printed robot, which we used as a base model for our future goal of making a 3D-printed life-sized hand able to do American Sign Language.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Esther Septimo, Kristin Angel, sudmun habib, Joshua Hilton, Antoun Obied, George Matta, Tajbid Rahman, Jonathan Dickinson

engineeringPark.name: RIT Launch Initiative: High Powered Rocketry
engineeringPark.description: This year's Launch Initiative exhibit will involve the much-anticipated unveiling of the nine-foot-long, level two high powered rocket "Hephaestus I" and the next generation of our level three high-powered competition rocket. The Launch Initiative will also be displaying our many level one launch vehicles as well as our footage from previous flights.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Thomas Skudlarek, Zachary Rizzolo, Forrest Shooster, Oldarlyn Castillo, Andrew Mashayekhi, Eric Roth, Hunter Collins, Bailey Reid, Matthew Davern, Abhishek Shah, Zoe-Jerusha Beepat, Kyle Tevis

engineeringPark.name: RIT Observatory Upgrade
engineeringPark.description: The goal of this project is to upgrade the observatory dome at RIT to allow easier observation of stellar objects so that more time can be put into analysing collect data.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Raymond Castro, Joseph Brescia, Wilson Quizhpi, Susan Farnand, Ahmed Alhurubi, Sarah Williams

engineeringPark.name: Robocomposter: The Automation of Composting
engineeringPark.description: Composting is a technique that can be used to take food and other organic waste, a significant contributor to landfill waste, and convert it to useful fertilizer. Robocomposter is a prototype of an automated machine that can grind, transport, and accelerate the process of composting. This prototype is fully automatic and can shred down any kitchen waste and transport the waste through the composter to accelerate the composting process.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Charles Friedman, Emir Ljuca, Dante Gonzales, John Maguire

engineeringPark.name: Robot - Escape the Maze!
engineeringPark.description: Robot games, maze mapping robots, Race your robot versus an autonomous robot. Escape the maze guarded by robot sentries.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Paul Lane, Daniel Kaputa, Clark Hochgraf, Josef DeHaan, Michael McLeod, Corey Pardee, Derrick Cosco, Mike Valentin, Marc Schwartz, Hasnain Akhtar, Aditya Gopinath, Angelena Russo, Sarah Jeter, Joseph Rondinelli, Shantel Green, Aliana Tejeda, Liam Nelson, Jodi-Ann Morgan, David Tassoni

engineeringPark.name: Robotic Musical Chimes (1st year eng. students)
engineeringPark.description: Visitors will be able to listen to and see working student-designed robotic music machines.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Mario Gomes, Zach Angelli, Jacob Lin, Carter Miller, Clayton Terry, Carl Burkhard, Derek Gagnon, Ben Hartman, Omkar Borse, Stuart Hull, Kristin Komendowski, Jacob Gutwirth, Jacob Warner, James Badstuebner, Rhys Thompson, Garrett Waldron, Benjamin Wolfrom, Eric L'Heureux, Will Sheppard, Olivia Vidmar, Amanda Weiss, Walker Hare, Sari Houchaimi, Kayla Llanos, Mitch Allen, Cesar Felipe, Max Sample, Joseph Samuelson, Torie Adler, Sean Clark, Dana Eschler, Jonathan Roux, Neil Bhasme, Caroline Feyling, Aleesha LeRuzic, Sara Zuwiyya

engineeringPark.name: Robots and Artificial Intelligence
engineeringPark.description: This exhibit displays reserach being done in the Multi Agent Bio-Robotics Laboratory in the following fields: Assistive technologies Machine learning Industrial robotics Computer vision
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Shitij Kumar, Tucker Graydon, Ferat Sahin, Matthew Haywood, Alexander Synesael, Celal Savur, Mazin Ali, Mark Pitonyak, Cassandra Derr, Felisa Sze, Bryan Harper, Chloe Bohlman, Steven Giewont, Vishnunandan Venkatesh , Akash Saha

engineeringPark.name: Rotating Dynamometer to Measure Cutting Forces
engineeringPark.description: Machining everyday items like cars, cell phones, or aviation parts need to be made with the highest precision and accuracy possible. There is a constant struggle to find the most accurate way to measure and analyze the cutting force of a machine or tool. In doing so, processes like these can be optimized and drive the cost down for companies, and in turn the consumers. Come see the first step in finding the best optimization.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Joseph Amoia, Muhammad Ibraheem, Elbert Heacock, Zac Rubeor, Brian Coren

engineeringPark.name: Rube Goldberg
engineeringPark.description: A Rube Goldberg chain reaction machine designed to entertain and teach. Young and old will learn a bit about engineering and the Society of Women Engineers' K-12 program, SWE Next, at an engaging and educational exhibit.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Melissa Rideout, Kayla Stephan, Allyssa Cio, Margaret Coulter, Johanna Carroll, Rachel Berry, Danielle Fischer, Melissa Nellist, Meghan Britt, Marissa Burkland, Shelly Mason, Lauren Cussen, Melissa Dubots, Erin Reilly, Emilie MacKinnon, Erin Petrillose, Melissa Valdez, Laura Moon, Alexa Kline, Melissa Calopiz, Julia Provenzano, Hope DiVello, Maggie Brooks, Megan Ritting, Paula Zaretzky, Kyla Driver, Mary McCombs, Nicole Freitag

engineeringPark.name: Sandia Instrumented 3D Printer
engineeringPark.description: One of the most important areas of growth for 3D printing is temperature control. This printer is a commercial printer that has been fitted with an observation network created by our team, which allows the user to record values critical to the build process such as bed temperature and atmospheric temperature while also using a thermal camera to observe the print. Take home a small 3D print from the event as a token of our appreciation!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Michael Muldoon, Justin Rueb, Jon Eames, Ryan Thorna, Jacob Lowe, Ed Hanzlik

engineeringPark.name: ShingleBot: The Future of Robotic Construction
engineeringPark.description: ShingleBot is a robotic shingle removing system controlled via Bluetooth Remote Controller. We have adapted cameras, sensors and actuators to assist the user in tearing off shingles in the fastest, most effective and safest way to date. Come check out the next generation of construction roofing with our battle bot style robot and watch the shingles fly!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: William Lawrie, Brendan Flaherty, Thomas Schwartz, Alicia Kirk, MaryCatherine Murphy, Mark Underhill, David Durfee, Daniel Kaputa

engineeringPark.name: Sigma Sigma Sigma Presents Sign Idol
engineeringPark.description: We are advertising our event Sign Idol. For those of you who do not know what it is, it is similar to American Idol but with ASL. We will be having three judges and those who are performing have a chance to win prizes. It is loads of fun and a great event for the Deaf and Hearing community to come together. (Please note that no ticket sales will occur during Imagine RIT.)
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Cassandra Sinnott

engineeringPark.name: Solar Thermal Water Heater
engineeringPark.description: Solar thermal water heating is a great way to see how the sun's power can be harnessed. Come check out how you can capture the sun's energy and use it to heat water without burning coal or natural gas. The advantages of flat plate solar thermal technology is that it is a clean and renewable source of energy. The only thing that needs power is a pump. Come see how we put the sun to work for us!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Sarah Kirk, Alex Slabyk, Deven Greenawalt, MiKe Pastore, Evan Baileys

engineeringPark.name: Solar Transpired Crop Dryer
engineeringPark.description: Come see us sun dry bananas! Our crop dryer passively warms the air using solar radiation to dry bananas for the intention of preventing crop spoilage after large harvests in Haiti.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Kaleigh Sweeney, Louis Kline, Matt Hossack, Kelsey Clements

engineeringPark.name: SportsNet Storage Facility Improvements
engineeringPark.description: SportsNet provided those with disabilities the opportunity to enjoy adaptive sports and recreational activities including cycling, skiing and golfing. Many of these require specialized equipment requiring storage space, provided by SportsNet, while not in use. Initially their storage facility was not efficiently organized and contained safety hazards. The goal of this project was to improve the space utilization within the unit to make storing and locating equipment more efficient and safer.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Sarah Harley, Samantha Cali Smith , Brady Hawkes, Peter Larson, Ed Hanzlik, Michael Cocquyt

engineeringPark.name: St. Joseph's House of Hospitality Improvements
engineeringPark.description: St. Joseph's House of Hospitality is a homeless shelter in downtown Rochester. Our senior design team worked with St. Joseph's staff to make improvements in their shelter operations.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Sharon Im, Ezra Weinstein, Ken Postel, Allyson Komrowski, Connor Pierce

engineeringPark.name: Sunspot Radio Telescope
engineeringPark.description: Sunspots are massive dark spots on the Sun's surface that emit large quantities of radiation, for reasons not fully understood. Working with another sunspot astronomy team in Zurich, SZ, the Astronomy Section at the Rochester Academy of Sciences recently realized there are no solar radio telescopes in the Northeastern US. Our project is intended to clear up that blind spot, and provide ASRAS and Zurich astronomers and student researchers with the ability to study these phenomena.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Brendan Parke, jeff kaiser, Adam Hargrave, Nanthiel Peck, Zachary Smith, Jeffrey Sylor, Martin Pepe

engineeringPark.name: Tesla Turbine
engineeringPark.description: A bladeless turbine that was first patented in 1913 by Nikola Tesla. This iteration is constructed using hard drive platters encased in a chassis that was designed with AutoCad software. The turbine is capable of reaching up to 15,000 rpm.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Scott Williamson, Daniel Yochim, Samuel Shelmidine , Carl Burkhard, Michael Smith, Sarah Ehrhardt, Chris Witmer

engineeringPark.name: The Amazing Microchip
engineeringPark.description: Come and learn how microchips are fabricated in the RIT Semiconductor & Microsystems Fabrication Laboratory. . The dimensions are extremely small, with feature sizes in the nanometer range - over a hundred of them can fit across the width of a human hair! You will see how raw material is transformed into crystalline silicon wafers, and get an overview of the manufacturing process.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Karl Hirschman, Tarun Mudgal, Ryan Hirschman, Eli Powell

engineeringPark.name: The Endless Possibilities of Secondhand Clothing
engineeringPark.description: Textile waste is one of the largest growing problems in the modern world. Many clothing companies are now trying to create sustainable methods of manufacturing and recycling both synthetic and natural fibers. Our project aims to explore these methods and create practical business models for our local Goodwills. Come check out our exhibit and take a sneak peek at the future of sustainable textiles!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Valeria Villa, Erin Podhaisky, Corey King, Pauline Dziama, Catheryn McCarthy

engineeringPark.name: The Gear Chair
engineeringPark.description: The Gear Chair is a wheelchair that utilizes gear hub technology, which allows for a better mechanical advantage. This allows one to propel oneself quicker, move more easily up a hill, or traverse grassy terrain.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Collin Inglut, Alexa Hurlbert, Curran Tobin, Justin McKee, Ryan Hoyt

engineeringPark.name: The Next Revolution: Integrated Photonics
engineeringPark.description: Integrated Photonics will one day revolutionize technology by providing: cheap health diagnostic systems, and three dimensional LIDAR that will be used in self driving cars and household robots. See these photonic chips and demonstrations of the concepts that will power these chips, including, optical internet connections, infrared camera technology, wave phenomena and more!
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Stefan Preble, Zihoa Wang, Abdelsalam Aboketaf, Peichuan Yin, Michael Fanto

engineeringPark.name: Toyota Production Systems Lab
engineeringPark.description: The lab showcases production systems which includes assembly lines and warehousing systems, and which can be extended into other areas such as health care. There will be some form of interactive activity (which we are still designing!)
engineeringPark.exhibitors: John Kaemmerlen, Sidharaj Jadeja, Vaibhav Rungta, Kavish Kathawala, Rahul Kikani, Allyssa Cio, Arden Bonzo, Taylor Smith, Joseph Kleinberger, Rachel Berry, Liz Millar, Siddharth Garg, Gavin Lim, Elmas Koc, Fahd Almassri, Saurabh Paralikar, Ricardo Yupanqui Rivera, Dan Fox, Brady Sweeny

engineeringPark.name: TRAK TECHNOLOGY FOR LOW/MEDIUM VOLUME PRODUCTION
engineeringPark.description: See TRAK CNC equipment in operation and how they are used in industry for product development. Southwestern Industries Demonstration Area. Gleason Room 9-2430 Mechanical Engineering machine shop
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Jan Maneti, Craig Arnold, Mick Wilkinson, Thomas Balmer, Ed Szozda

engineeringPark.name: Vacuum Former at The Construct
engineeringPark.description: Live demonstration of vacuum forming using a student developed vacuum former. Located in The Construct (INS-4190), the project was designed and built by MSD Team 17676.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Nicholas VanderWeide, Nicholas Reed, Steven Henning, Luca Verdi, Alicia Sutphin

engineeringPark.name: Xerox UV-Curing Ink Jetting Printer
engineeringPark.description: A senior design project for creating an ink-jetting printer which utilizes ink which cures via ultraviolet light. This ink can be jetted onto a flat surface such as glass, and cured nearly instantly with a ultraviolet light. This printer has ability to move in the vertical direction, allowing for multiple layers of the ink to be jetted and cured on top of each other. Visitors may view the system and ask questions related to its operation and applications.
engineeringPark.exhibitors: Andrew Fisher, Bocephus Leduc, Mark Swamy, Jose Salas, Charles Dixon, Derek Witt
